title: Dead biker’s mum breaks down as she begs diplomat’s wife to ‘do the right thing’
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

The mother of Harry Dunn has tearfully appealed for his alleged killer to ‘get on the plane and do the humane thing’.

Appearing on Good Morning Britain, Charlotte Charles spoke directly to Anne Sacoolas, who left the UK despite being involved in a car crash which killed the 19-year-old in August.

Last night, the family met Preside Donald Trump and turned down the opportunity to meet the diplomat’s wife after being told she was also in the White House.

Charlotte said she and partner Tim Dunn had considered that the President might ‘spring that on us’ during their meeting, but said they were ‘shocked’ when he ultimately did.

She said: ‘We do still want to meet Anne but we’ve said all along that it needs to be on UK soil, and that she needs to come back to the UK to face our justice system.

Charlotte Charles was interviewed on Good Morning Britain after her meeting with Trump (Picture: ITV)

Harry Dunn was killed in head-on collision in August (Picture: Justice 4 Harry)

‘We don’t want [Harry’s] death swept under the carpet.’

Asked what she would say to Anne directly, Charlotte continued: ‘I would just ask her to get on the plane and do the humane thing.

‘Set her children a good example. We raised our children to be as honest as the day is long. Her children must be suffering.

‘We believe two of them were in the car and we can’t imagine what they are going through either. She needs to do the right thing and make that decision herself.’

Charlotte also told presenters Piers Morgan and Susanna Reid that she had pleaded with Trump directly to help the family get justice for Harry.

She appealed directly to Anne Sacoolas and asked her to ‘get on a plane’ (Picture: ITV)

She said: ‘At the end, while leaving the room, he shook all our hands again and I was last in line.

‘When he held my hand, I gripped it a lot tighter and I was honest with him and just said, “If this was your son, surely you’d be doing the same thing”.

‘He actually gripped my hand a little bit tighter and said, “Yes, I would be”. I told him to please, please, do the right thing, please just try.

‘He said he would try to look at this from another angle. I don’t really know what he meant by that or what time scale we’re expecting, but it felt sincere.’

Harry was killed in a head-on collision with a Volvo, which had been on the wrong side of the road, near RAF Croughton, on August 27.

Mrs Sacoolas had been granted diplomatic immunity at first

Mrs Sacoolas has previously said she was ‘terribly sorry’ about the incident, adding that she had ‘no time to react’ when she saw his motorbike.

She had been interviewed by police after the crash but then returned to the US after claiming diplomatic immunity through her husband, who is a US intelligence official.

However that protection is now in dispute, with the Foreign Office stating it no longer applies because Mrs Sacoolas left the UK.

description: Appearing on Good Morning Britain, Charlotte Charles spoke directly to Anne Sacoolas after her son Harry Dunn was killed in a head-on crash.
